sections.content:
Warm-up (2-3 min)

be/bei review:

The giver of books to me → ?
The seller of X to Y for Z → lo vecnu be ? bei ? bei ?

(Answers: lo dunda be lo cukta bei mi, be X bei Y bei Z)

New Material (5-7 min)

New Vocabulary

Lojban Place Structure English
sitna x1 cites/quotes x2 for audience x3 cite/quote/refer
bacru x1 utters/says x2 utter/say (phonemes)

Why be'o?

be'o terminates the be/bei structure. Without it, ambiguity can arise.

The Ambiguity Problem

lo vecnu be lo cukta poi barda

Ambiguous! Does poi barda modify cukta or vecnu?

  • The seller of (books which are big)?
  • The (seller of books) who is big?

Using be'o

lo vecnu be lo cukta be'o poi barda

The seller of books, who is big.

The be'o closes the be-structure, so poi attaches to vecnu.

Without be'o

lo vecnu be lo cukta poi barda

The seller of books which are big.

(Here poi attaches to cukta.)

When be'o is Optional

At the end of a description or before cu, be'o is often elidable:

lo vecnu be lo cukta cu klama

The seller of books goes. (be'o not needed before cu)

Key Point

Use be'o to separate the be-structure from relative clauses or other grammar.

sections.content:
Practice (4-5 min)

Exercise 1: With be'o

Translate (the relative clause modifies the main noun):

  1. The seller of books, who is big.
  2. The giver of apples, who is happy.
  3. The reader of poems, who is beautiful.
Answers
  1. lo vecnu be lo cukta be'o poi barda
  2. lo dunda be lo plise be'o poi gleki
  3. lo tcidu be lo pemci be'o poi melbi

Exercise 2: Without be'o

Translate (the relative clause modifies the x2):

  1. The seller of books which are big.
  2. The reader of poems which are beautiful.
  3. The giver of apples which are red.
Answers
  1. lo vecnu be lo cukta poi barda
  2. lo tcidu be lo pemci poi melbi
  3. lo dunda be lo plise poi xunre

Exercise 3: New Vocabulary

Translate:

  1. I cite a book.
  2. Alice utters words.
  3. I quote the sentence.
Answers
  1. mi sitna lo cukta
  2. la .alis. cu bacru lo valsi
  3. mi sitna lo jufra

sections.content:
Conversation Challenge (1-2 min)

Say aloud:

  1. "The seller of books, who is tall." → lo vecnu be lo cukta be'o poi clani
  2. "I cite a sentence." → mi sitna lo jufra
  3. "The writer of poems which are good." → lo ciska be lo pemci poi xamgu

Summary

You learned be'o to close be-structures. Use it when relative clauses or other grammar follows.
